typeData.textContent:
A cohort is basically a group of people who have shared a particular event together during a particular time span.The most commonly studied cohorts are age-related. Examples included people sharing the same birthday, growing up in the same region during the same time period and also people who were exposed to the same natural disaster.
A cohort effect is a research result that occurs because of the characteristics of the cohort being studied. Cohort effects are important to take into account in research. Cohort effects can compromise the results of research that uses cross-sectional methods. Even longitudinal design may have cohort effects. They are important in developmental studies because they can be confounding variables.
In order to determine whether a cohort effect is present, a researcher may conduct a cohort study.A cohort study is a particular form of longitudinal study that samples a cohort performing a cross-section at intervals through time. 

References:

https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cohort_study
https://www.thoughtco.com/cohort-effect-definition-4582483

Authoritative vs Authoritarian parenting style (Isaaca Wang)

typeData.textContent:
Is the Authoritative parenting style the ideal parenting style?

The psychosocial and emotional development of children is influenced by
their caregivers' parenting styles. The formation of a child's self-concept is
often shaped by whether their parents exercise an Authoritarian, Authoritative,
Permissive, or Uninvolved parenting style. Although the Authoritative parenting
style is accepted as the ideal parenting style in Western society, the
Authoritarian style of parenting can be just as effective - with respect to
certain conditions. This piece of writing will explore the complex nature of
the Authoritarian parenting style, a parenting style often externalized as the
disciplinary practices of guilt induction, love withdrawal, or a combination of
both. Guilt induction is evoking the feeling of guilt by personalizing the consequences
of the child's behavior in an attempt to change that behavior. Love withdrawal
involves manipulating feelings of acceptance as a sign of disapproval by
withholding friendliness, warmth, and/or attention, indicating to the child
that they are loved only if they comply to their parentâ€™s demands.

A recent study aimed to discover whether there is a correlation between the usage guilt induction/love withdrawal and a tendency for the affected child to engage in bullying behaviors at school (Yu, Cheah, Hart, Yang, & Olsen, 2019). The population demographic that this research examines is 133 first-generation Chinese American mothers and their preschool children. In the experimental procedure, preschool teachers rated the childrenâ€™s frequency of bullying behaviors on a five-point scale based on various means of assessment, such as â€œkicks other children for the sake of itâ€ and â€œmakes fun of peersâ€™ possessionsâ€. Using the same measurement scale, the mothers rated the frequency of their usage of guilt induction and love withdrawal. The researchers then used the data to calculate the degree of correlation between the two variables. The results show no salient effects of guilt induction on bullying but do show negative effects of love withdrawal on social aggression. This illustrates the negative consequences of the disciplinary practice of love withdrawal; during which the parent appears to stop loving their child. Although the parent, in most cases, does continue to love the child, the child does not perceive it as such; thus, it is unclear to the child that the parent unconditionally loves them. This form of psychological assault not only jeopardizes the parent-child relationship but contributes to various forms of maladjustment during childhood, including the aggressive bullying behaviors exemplified in this study. Guilt induction, however, did not affect the Chinese American children in the study. Interestingly, in individualistic cultures like the US, guilt induction may be felt as parental rejection or lack of parental support. Accordingly, it would hinder positive development in European-American children. However, in collectivist cultures like many Asian cultures, children often interpret guilt induction as concern and caring for their well-being on the part of the parent instead of parental rejection; this is due to being raised in a cultural context that emphasizes a more interconnected sense of self. As such, whether an Authoritarian parenting style is effective or not depends on ethnicity/culture and the disciplinary practices employed. Children of certain Asian ethnicities whose parents did not use love withdrawal usually undergo a healthy emotional development and the formation of a positive self-concept, thus dispelling the popular conception that the Authoritative parenting style is the universally ideal parenting style.

Yu, J., Cheah, C. S. L., Hart, C. H., Yang, C., & Olsen, J. A. (2019). Longitudinal effects of maternal love withdrawal and guilt induction on Chinese American preschoolersâ€™ bullying aggressive behavior.Â Development and Psychopathology,Â 31(04), 1467â€“1475. doi: 10.1017/s0954579418001049

The Effects of Parenting Styles and Childhood Attachment Patterns (Psyched12- Aman Padda)

typeData.textContent:
The type of attachment that a child forms has long-term repercussions into many aspects of the child's development and adult life. Some of these aspects include peer relationships and the ability to maintain long-term intimate relationships. 

Persons with secure childhood attachments show higher levels of trust, closeness, and dependability while insecure childhood attachments predict the reverse.

 The authoritative parent is sensitive to the child's needs, does not use punitive discipline, and reasons with the child in a loving and affectionate manner. This type of parenting is usually found to form secure attachment styles in children. 

Comparatively, the authoritarian parent is demanding, but unresponsive to the child, tends to use punitive and harsh punishment, physical enforcement, reprimands, and prohibitive interventions. The outcomes of authoritarian parenting tend to overlap the characteristics of avoidant attachment. The children of authoritarian parents have been described as anxious, angry, aggressive, and having low self-esteem.

Permissive parents make few demands and rarely use punishment. They tend to be very nurturing and loving, and may play the role of friend rather than parent. Children of permissive parents have low self-control and self-reliance, and are very immature.

nodes.title: The Development of self-concept (Anna Malikovskaia psyched12)
nodes.description: Brief summary of early development of self-concept in children

typeData.textContent: By the age of 18 months toddlers start developing a self-concept. Before that age they cannot recognize themselves in the mirror. The establishment of self-concept occurs between the ages 2-4. This means that they can label themselves with gender, cooperate with other children, have little anxiety separating from their parents. At this age children show autonomy, can initiate and complete plans. They also have difficulty sharing their possessions with others, but by the age of 4 share when asked. Children learn to identify themselves as group members as well as discover personality traits of others and themselves by the age of 6. When children start school, they start comparing themselves to their peers and also recognize that they are more skilled and knowledgeable in some areas than in others. Positive self-concept is important in the development of self-confidence. Many factors shape the development of self-concept and one of the most important is parenting style.

Little Hans Case Study (Heyden Lam, HEH24)

typeData.textContent:
Little Hans was a 5-year-old boy that had a phobia of horses. A prominent event that marked his phobia was when he saw a horse fall down when it was carrying a heavy cart. Hans said this experience was frightening because he dislikes the sound of horses falling down and their hooves clattering against the concrete. Another event that seems to connect with Hansâ€™ fear of horses was when he was 3 years old (during the phallic stage of the psychosexual development stages), he had a strong interest in his own â€œwiddlerâ€ (penis) and those of others. His mother told him to stop touching his â€œwiddlerâ€ or else she would ask a doctor to cut it off. Sigmund Freud, a popular psychologist at the time found Hansâ€™ case very interesting and decided to help him overcome his fear.

Due to Hansâ€™ fear of horses, he developed an anxiety of going out of his house because they lived across a busy coaching inn and many horses were around the area. When Hans was asked which specific type of horses he was afraid of, he provided a very detailed answer. Hans disliked white horses with black bits around their mouths that wear blinkers. Additionally, Hansâ€™ father had more in-depth conversations with Hans and discovered that Hans was afraid that a horse will bite off his â€œwiddlerâ€ and this fear was somehow connected to being frightened by the sight of a large penis. From these sets of information, Freud realized that the horses Hans was afraid of is actually his father. Hans was scared that his father would castrate him for having incestuous desires towards his mother. The characteristics of the horses that Hans disliked were actually his fatherâ€™s, as he has pale skin, a moustache and wears glasses. 

Freud diagnosed Hans with Oedipus complex, where a child develops sexual desires for the opposite-sex parent and becomes jealous of the same-sex parent for receiving affection from the other parent. Oedipus complex occurs during the phallic stage of psychosexual development, between the ages of 3 and 6. The fear that the father might find out his son has sexual feelings towards the mother often leads to castration anxiety, which is the fear that the father will cut off the sonâ€™s penis. In order to manage this anxiety, the son will likely start adopting the fatherâ€™s behaviour, attitudes, and values to prevent conflicts from arising. This behaviour is also known as identification with the aggressor. Oedipus complex can be mostly resolved by having the father directly tell his son that he does not want to castrate him.

typeData.textContent: Autism Spectrum Disorder is a developmental disorder that affects an individualâ€™s social skill, communication skills, and behavior towards certain situations. Autism is generally discovered at a young age. The signs are telling as a childâ€™s development differ from the â€˜normsâ€™. Some signs include being unresponsive to their name, social isolation from other children, repetitive behavior (flapping their hands or rocking their body), avoiding eye contact, etc. This disorder causes a child to develop at a different rate and order than other children. It affects a childâ€™s joint attention; using eye contact and gestures to express themselves with others. This poses a challenge with the childâ€™s ability to successful communicate with others, including the parents, as well as language skills. Often, children on the Autism spectrum is unable to create a relation between the a word of an object with a picture of the object; example, they would not make the connection of a picture of a dog with the word â€˜dogâ€™. The inability to process joint attention can hinder a childâ€™s capacity to learn certain skills like taking turns, reading facial expressions, staying with a topic of a conversation, etc. The most common and telling sign of this disorder is an individualâ€™s lack of social skills. This incompetence to interpret social cues comes from their inability to see things from other peopleâ€™s perspectives; they are unable to understand and empathize with other peopleâ€™s desires, feelings, and beliefs, if it so happen to be different from their own. This results in a difficulty getting along with other people as many find this behavior rude and insulting. However, the intention of the matter is never cruel, itâ€™s simply due to the fact that a child suffering with ASD would not understand why a person would be upset in a given situation; they simply donâ€™t understand. Although, this disorder tends to hinder a childâ€™s development early on in their years, if the disorder is caught early, the certain gaps of knowledge and skill building can be devised to help a child understand the world around them and live with Autism.

nodes.title: Case Study: Cognitive Development of children with ASD - Rain Zhang

typeData.textContent:
People with autism spectrum disorder (ASD) are thought to have a specific profile of cognitive strengths and weaknesses -- difficulties appreciating others' thoughts and feelings, problems regulating and controlling their behavior, and an enhanced ability to perceive details -- but few studies have tracked children's cognitive skills over time. Now new longitudinal research provides clues that can inform our understanding of ASD.

Research conducted at Western Australia in 2010 assessed 37 children with ASD and 31 typically developing children when they were 5 to 6 years old and again three years later. The study explored the children's ability to perceive others' behavior based on their thoughts and feelings (theory of mind) by asking children to watch a series of social interactions on video and predict a character's behavior based on his or her mental state. The study then assessed the children's ability to self-regulate their behavior (executive function) by having them take part in problem-solving tasks that required them to plan ahead and show flexibility. And the study assessed children's aptitude for detecting parts of objects or small details (central coherence) by asking them to construct patterns from wooden blocks and search for shapes hidden in pictures.

The study found that children with ASD exhibited the same profile that's typically associated with ASD, both at the start of the study and three years later.  But a closer look at individual children's patterns of performance revealed that not all children with ASD displayed the same profile of cognitive strengths and weaknesses. Instead, the profiles of cognitive skills varied from one participant to the next: For example, while one child with ASD showed difficulties in theory of mind alone, another child showed problems in theory of mind plus executive function.

These findings encourage the importance of understanding the breadth of cognitive skills in children with ASD, and how these skills progress over time. A key question for the future is whether there are approaches that can facilitate progress in some of these areas.

Early Childhood Education and Cognitive Development (Emma Wong)
nodes.description: Discussing research conduct by Hart and Risley as well as Weikart, this node outlines the effects early childhood education has on cognitive and intellectual development.

typeData.textContent:
The argument of nature vs. nurture in regards to cognitive development, personality development, and intellectual development has spanned over decades. Research suggests that what a child experiences in their early life has a lasting impact on the development of their brain. While genes are the â€œroadmapâ€ of our development, experiences create the neural connections that set the foundations of our emotions, language, motor skills, vision and memories.

Betty Hart and Todd Risley (2006) studied families of different socioeconomic stations to look at early language ability and progression (OpenStax 2018). While children of low-income families were exposed to an approximate 600 words per hour, children from middle- to high-income families were exposed to around 200 words ,per hour. By the age of 3, the gap becomes 30 million words (OpenStax, 2018). Additionally, Hart and Risley found that, before entering kindergarten, high-income children scored, on average, 60% higher on achievement tests than those from low-income families.

Using a longitudinal study, David Weikart and his colleagues studied the effects of pre-school education on the achievements and lifestyles of children. Weikart and his team randomly divided 123 underprivileged kids into 2 groups. One group spent 2 years in a prestigious preschool with attentive teachers while the other group did not attend such a pre-school (Sprouts, 2017). After the two years and an additional 40 years in the longitudinal study, Weikart and his team published their findings. The team found that at the age of 5, 67% of the children from the top pre-school group had an IQ greater than 90 and were school ready while only 28% of those who didnâ€™t attend were ready for school. At the age of 14, there was a large difference between basic classroom achievements. By 37, the top pre-school group was more likely to own their own home. At the age of 40, the top pre-school group was more likely to earn more money (Sprouts, 2017). Weikart and his team concluded that the 2 years in the preschool aided in cognitive and social development, teaching them attitudes (such as grit) that were useful in their later years (Sprouts, 2017).


References

OpenStax, Psychology. OpenStax CNX. Oct 31, 2018.

Sprouts. (2017, Jun 9). Early Childhood Education: The Research [Video]. Youtube. 
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=NNgp1_B-6c8

nodes.title: Psychosocial theory of development (Bita Ghorbani)

typeData.textContent:
The psychosocial theory of development is a theory which was created by Erik Erikson in an attempt to figure out how humans develop into adults. Erikson was a stage theorist which means that he believed that development occurs in stages and is therefore discontinous. With his psychosocial theory,  he focused on the social aspect of our development and believed that in each stage of a human's life there is a psychosocial task that we must master in order to feel competent. Erikson also believed that development was an event that occurred throughout the entire lifespan of a human. 

       Erikson proposed that there are eight stages of development during our lifespan, each with a task at hand to complete. Here, I will go through each of the eight stages briefly to give an idea of the tasks that are present at the various stages. 

     In stage 1, trust vs mistrust is our developmental task and this occurs from birth to twelve months of age. Here, if infants are treated with attention and sensitivity from their caregivers, they will see the world as a safe place, whereas if an infant was treated poorly they may look at the world negatively as an unsafe environment. Stage 2 occurs during the ages 1-3, and this focuses on the task of autonomy vs shame. If a toddler is able to perform a task independently, they will feel a positive sense of independence, but if they are denied the chance of being able to perform independently, they will feel ashamed in themselves and develop a lack of self esteem. 

         Stage 3 occurs from ages 3-6 and the task is initiative vs guilt. In this stage, one will feel a sense of guilt if they are unable to be successful in a situation where they are taking initiative, but if they succeed, they will develop confidence. Stage 4 occurs from ages 7-11 and here the task is industry vs inferiority. In this stage, if one is competent, they will feel confident whereas if they are not they will develop a sense of inferiority. Stage 5 occurs from ages 12-18 and the task at hand is identity vs confusion. Here the task is to develop a sense of self, and so those that are successful in this task will feel a good sense of identity, whereas those who are not will be confused and feel unsure of their identity.

        Stage 6 occurs from ages 19-29 and here there is a task of intimacy vs isolation, where if one is unable to be intimate they will develop a very lonely feeling. Stage 7 occurs from ages 30-64 and the task is generativity vs stagnation. One will feel like they are in a state of stagnation if they do not succeed in tasks that contribute to the development of others such as raising children or volunteering. And lastly, stage 8 occurs from the ages of 65 to the end of life where the task is integrity vs dispair where people who feel proud of their accomplishments of their life as they are looking back will develop a sense of integrity, but if one looks back at their life with regrets about what they should have done they will develop a sense of dispair. 

     According to Erikson, through the completion of each task, one will develop a healthy personality and a good sense of competence. Negatively, if one fails to complete a task they will develop a feeling that they are inadequate.

nodes.title: Erikson's Psychological Stages (Maegan Chong)
Week 7: Freudâ€™s Psychosexual Theory of Development (Shawn Yee)
nodes.description: A deeper look into Freud's psychosexual theory of development, briefly mentioned in the lectures but never expanded on.

typeData.textContent:
A springboard for Eriksonâ€™s psychosocial theory of development was Freudâ€™s psychosexual theory of development, with five main stages, in a specific order: oral, anal, phallic, latency, and genital. Freudâ€™s main thesis was that children go through these stages of development that ultimately coalescence into oneâ€™s personality. In this case, the â€œ-sexualâ€ suffix used by Freud was more broadly defined as activities which resulted in pleasure. Any over-stimulation or under-stimulation, referred to as overindulgence and frustration respectively in any stage would result in â€œfixationâ€ in that particular stage, which would eventually lead to certain abnormalities in oneâ€™s personality.

The first main stage described by Freud is the oral stage, ranging from birth to around 2 years of age. During this phase, the main source of pleasure is derived form orally related activities, such as thumb-sucking and breast feeding. If a person were to become fixated in this stage, behaviours such as alcoholism, smoking, and other orally related activities would arise later in life.

This pattern continues for the next few stages. In the anal stage, from around age 2 to 3, where the child gains pleasure from defecating. An overindulgence in his stage may result in overly messy or disorganized lifestyles, while a frustration may result in an obsession with cleanliness.

In the phallic stage, from ages 3 to 6, a child would begin to start desiring their opposite-sex parent, which would eventually lead to either castration anxiety for males or penis envy in females. This is resolved with a process referred to as identification, where male children start to act and behave like their fathers and females adopt the â€œfemale gender roleâ€ based on their mothers. Fixations on this stage may lead to a weak sense of sexual identity in the future.

From ages 6 to puberty, the child undergoes a latency stage, where all pleasurable desires are repressed in favour of socialization with other peers, particularly those of the same sex, sharing hobbies and interests.

Finally, in the genital stage, which begins from puberty onwards, the teenagerâ€™s desire once again turns to members of the opposite sex, and eventually develop into functioning members of society with the desire to procreate and ensure the survival of humanity.    

Obviously, there are some major criticisms surrounding Freudâ€™s psychosexual theory of development, and one of the most prominent ones is that his theory is unfalsifiable, a trait which is necessary in any scientific theory. Some additions criticisms include the heteronormativity especially present in the phallic and genital stages, as well as possibly implying that children of single-parent households may develop abnormal personalities. However, despite these criticisms, one undisputed fact is that Freudâ€™s theories contributed majorly to the field of psychology, and his theories have also been a stepping stone for other, more scientific theories including Eriksonâ€™s.

Works Consulted:

McLeod, S. A. (2019, July 18). Psychosexual stages. Simply Psychology. https://www.simplypsychology.org/psychosexual.html

nodes.title: How Socioeconomic Status can Affect Child Development (Angelina Hollihn)
nodes.description: Social status can affect childhood development in terms of intelligence

typeData.textContent:
Group Name: MAA

There is research that shows a difference in IQ between individuals of higher SES and individuals of lower SES. This is known as the achievement gap, which shows a consistent gap in test scores, graduation rates, and grades. Experts believe this gap is due to the parenting difference between low and high SES families. Studies found that parents in high and middle SES families spoke more to their children. By speaking to children more, it increases their vocabulary at a younger age. This makes it easier for children to learn how to read, write, speak, and understand social cues. The IQ of an individual is based on the environment they grow up in as well as genetic factors. This is the cause of nature and nurture as we have learned in previous chapters. 

Long term poverty as well as low SES both create mental disorders and have a huge effect on mental health. A possible reason that parents in high-middle SES groups speak to their children more so than parents in lower SES groups is because they may have better mental health, as they are under less financial stress. They also may be less physically and mentally exhausted after work compared to families in lower SES groups. 

Betty Hart and Todd Risley (2006) were two psychologists who used a longitudinal study (study that uses the same variables, in this case people, over a long period of time) to learn how parents from different SES interact with their children. They found that middle and high income parents spoke to their children more, and by 3 years old the children knew nearly double the amount of words that the low income children knew. This gap became more prominent as the children aged. 

A solution for this problem that psychologists came up with is placing low SES children in schools with middle to high SES children. If children who have a smaller vocabulary are placed with children who have a larger vocabulary, this will help allow low SES children to catch up to their high SES peers. Another solution to this problem is that experts in this area of study are working in the homes of low income families, encouraging and helping parents bond and speak with their children. Other ways to help children from low income families thrive as well as children from high income families is to have them involved in community events and organizations. Such as dance classes, art classes, sport teams, summer camps. While these all cost money, there are many organizations that help fundraise for children that are less fortunate.

nodes.title: Patterns of Motor Development (Jamie Feng)
Newborn Reflexes and Depth Perception (Harleen Rattan)
nodes.description: This node teaches students more about innate newborn reflexes and what depth perception is.

typeData.textContent:
Newborn reflexes are automatic responses to particular forms of stimulation. The unique part about these reflexes is that they were never taught to the babies, they are innate.  Some of the reflexes that babies are born with include rooting, sucking, grasping, and moro. Elaborating on the sucking reflex, babies know that they need to use their mouths to suck in order to get milk. Imagine if babies did not know how to suckâ€¦they would feel hungry all the time as they wouldn't be able to know how to drink milk. 
Another interesting ability that children later develop is depth perception. Depth perception is the ability to see the world in 3D dimensions. Similar to newborn reflexes, depth perception in innate (partly), meaning that children are not taught it, they develop it themselves. The rest of it is developed by experience. 
An experiment called the â€œvisual cliff experimentâ€ was created in order to test the depth perception in children. In this experiment, a heavy Plexiglas is placed a foot more off the floor. One side of this glass is covered by a patterned fabric which makes the glass appear solid. The same fabric is placed on the floor below the glass; making it appear as if it were a cliff (Cherry, 2020). The child is then placed onto the glass and the childâ€™s caregiver stands on the other end of the glass (the side that appears as a cliff). If the child had developed depth perception, it would be reluctant to crawl towards the caregiver as it thinks it would fall into the cliff. On the other hand, if the child lacked depth perception, it would happily crawl towards the caregiver despite the â€œcliffâ€ in front of it (Cherry, 2020). 
I encourage you to watch this YouTube link to learn more about this experiment: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=DrzmvI6iMrE

Identity Formation and Toxic Masculinity (Nathan Cottell; Group: fernathan)

typeData.textContent: This course has shown how both Erikson and Marcia believed that identity formation, particularly during adolescence, is critical to psychological fitness. I think it is important to consider the intersection of gender norms with the stages of identity formation identified by these theorists. For many adolescents assigned male at birth in western cultures, the state of identity diffusion or moratorium described by Marcia can leave a person more vulnerable to the formation of toxic masculine behaviours such as emotional repression or misogyny. These behaviours have been reinforced by depictions in media for hundreds of years. In the next node, you can listen to a recording of me performing a monologue from Shakespeare's Much Ado about Nothing, written in the early 1600s. Check out how the speaker, Benedick, ridicules his good friend Claudio for being emotionally expressive and for having interests which diverge from traditional, martial, masculine ones. Benedick also has some very dismissive and misogynist views about women.

nodes.title: Concrete Operational Stage (Amir Amsyar Azizan)
Kohlberg's Theory of Moral Development (Halie Yelle)
Jean Piaget's Theory of Development (Claudia Le)
nodes.description: After spending many years studying childhood development, Jean Piaget developed a theory that explained how children's cognitive abilities went through specific stages.

typeData.textContent:
While there were many theories that focused on how children developed, Jean Piaget specifically focused on how they developed cognitively. Piaget viewed growth as discontinuous since he believed children's cognitive abilities took place in stages rather than improving on pre existing skills. 

As children grew, they developed schemata, concepts that helped them understand and organize information that they learned. When learning, children were to adjust schemata through assimilation or accomodation. Assimilation was incorporating new information comparable to our existing knowledge while accomodation was when children modified their schemata based on new experiences or information. 

Piaget said that there was 4 stages of cognitive development people went through: sensorimotor, preoperational, concrete operational, and formal operational. 

Sensorimotor lasted from birth to 2 years old. In this first stage, children are experiencing the world through their senses and actions. Children also develop object permanence in this stage, the act of understanding that if an object cannot be sensed, it still exists. Piaget also believed that babies develop stranger anxiety in this stage.

The next stage was the preoperational stage which lasted from the ages of 2 to 7 years old. While a child may have finally developed the ability to use words and pictures to to represent things, they lack logical reasoning for it. Children have yet to also understand the concept of conservation, they would likely think that if a jug of water was poured into two glasses, that there would be more water. Additionally, children will display egocentrism. Their logic is based on their own personal experiences, therefore, they think that everyone feels the same way as they do. 

The third stage Piaget introduced was called the concrete operational stage. Occurring from 7 to 11 years old, children are able to logically understand concepts and expected to perform basic mathematical transformations. They now understand conservation and reversibility as well, where objects can return back to their original form. 

The last stage lasts from 11 years old to adulthood. The formal operational stage explains that children are now able to think and understand abstract ideas. They develop the ability for moral reasoning and a renewed egocentrism may occur where adolescents fixate on something that others will not notice. 

Similar to many other theories, Piaget's theory of development has also come under criticism. Other studies believed that childhood development was more continuous, building on existing skills rather than taking place in different stages. Additionally, others thought that there was a fifth stage known as the postformal stage. In this stage, decisions were made based on context and logic is integrated with emotion to solve problems.

nodes.title: Schemata (BADGER102 - ERICA WON)

typeData.textContent:
I will be discussing schemata and the assimilation and accommodation of information.

A schemata is a concept that helps people categorize and interpret information. In order to learn new things, you can either assimilate new knowledge or accommodate your schema.

For example, a child grows up with a dog by her side. This dog is the only mammal she knows. It has 4 legs, and is incredibly furry and warm. Overtime, she has assimilated new knowledge into her schemata. Now she knows that dogs have 4 legs, fur, and warmth.

She then sees a cat for the first time ever! She notices that it also has 4 legs, fur, and warmth.

Despite the visual differences between a dog and a cat, the child proceeds to call the cat a â€œdogâ€, because she hasnâ€™t learned to differentiate between the two in her schema. In the same way we would call dogs and cats mammals, sheâ€™s assuming that both dogs and cats are â€œdogsâ€ because of similar traits (4 legs, fur, warmth).

Understanding a Schema in Psychology
Her dad tells her â€œNo, thatâ€™s not a dog. Itâ€™s a cat. It has a different body shape, different ears, and makes a different soundâ€. Now, the little child has accommodated her schemata to differentiate between dogs and cats. Dogs go â€œwoofâ€ and cats go â€œmeowâ€.

Additionally, schema bias can occur where oneâ€™s beliefs are resistant to change and influence oneâ€™s ability/willingness to accommodate new information. This results in prejudice, where one chooses NOT to accept the new information because it doesnâ€™t fit with their schema.

This can result in stereotypes and discrimination based on those stereotypes.

Schema Bias | Schema
In the photo above, we see how this person accepts information that is consistent with the schema.

For example, the 3rd picture shows of someone who has recently had an argument with their boyfriend. Because they heavily believe that â€œthey are unloveableâ€, this piece of information reinforces that belief. Unfortunately, the fact that theyâ€™ve been dating for 5 years nor the fact that a colleague came to visit them in the hospital doesnâ€™t matter, because this person is focusing on what fits her beliefs.

It is very important to recognize schema bias and address it accordingly. Oneâ€™s negative outlook on life can be very detrimental to their mental health. Similarly, oneâ€™s perception of a race/age/gender can lead to discrimination and unnecessary violence.

Correlations Between Parenting Styles and Attachment (John Sastrillo)

typeData.textContent:
As weâ€™ve seen in the past there have been several parenting styles and each one plays a role in the personalities of the child. When it comes to much younger children, weâ€™ve also seen different attachment types. From research done by Doinita and Maria in 2015 attempted to find a correlation between the attachment type of the child and the parenting style of their parent.
They started with 4 hypothesis where a Secure Adult Attachment would be positively correlated with an Authoritative parenting style, Dismissing Adult Attachment would be positively correlated with an Authoritarian parenting style, Preoccupied Adult Attachment would be positively correlated with a Permissive parenting style, and a Fearful Adult Attachment would also be positively correlated with a Permissive parenting style.
	From their experiment, Doinita and Maria found that there were positive correlations between a secure adult attachment and an authoritative parenting style. Similarly, they found there was a positive correlation between a fearful adult attachment and a permissive parenting style. For the other 2 hypotheses, they found no correlation.
This follows previous ideas weâ€™ve had that Authoritative parenting styles lead to a best case scenario for a childâ€™s development where they are more confident and secure in themselves. 

Citation:
Doinita, Nanu Elena, and Nijloveanu Dorina Maria. â€œAttachment and Parenting Styles.â€ Procedia - Social and Behavioral Sciences, vol. 203, 2015, pp. 199â€“204., doi:10.1016/j.sbspro.2015.08.282.

nodes.title: Test your knowledge of Piaget's Stage Theory (Minaho Sugimori (Chiew))
Piaget's Theory of Cognitive Development H5P Quiz (Marvin Wu)
The Creation and Comparison of the Moral Development and Cognitive Theory

typeData.textContent:
During week 7, there was a focus on different theories of lifespan development. In particular, we learned about emotional, personality and cognitive changes throughout childhood to late adulthood. It was interesting to notice how some theories â€œpiggybackedâ€ on concepts of a preceding psychologist, For example, the Moral Development Theory, created by Lawrence Kohlberg, was built upon the foundation of another theory. One of the most famous psychologists, Jean piaget, pioneered the 4 stages of development at different times in our lives, known as the Cognitive Theory of development. Both of these social psychologists focused on the childhood aspect of development, and were weary to the idea of cognitive thoughts and how they affect our behaviour. 

In the Cognitive Theory of Development, Jean Piaget proposed that there were four concrete stages. These were known as the sensorimotor, preoperational, concrete operational and formal operational. The sensorimotor stage focused on children who learned about the world through senses and motor behavior, and was during the ages of 0-2 years old. Afterwards, the preoperational phase, lasting from 2-7, the children begin to use language, display egocentrism, and have still not developed an understanding of conservation. The third stage at 7-11 years old is known as the concrete operational stage, where they begin to harness a knowledge of conservation, and use reasoning and logic to solve dilemmas. The last stage, formal development, involves people 11+ years old. This stage focused on abstract thinking. 

This was a great theory to explain the evolution of our behaviour and thoughts as we age, and which milestones we surpass every few years that contribute to our development. Armed with this knowledge, Kohldberg took these principles to create the Moral Development Theory. This involves moral reasoning, and is directly correlated to our cognitive development. 

The Moral Development Theory focused on childhood to adolescence development and our moral reasoning as we aged. According to Kohlberg, there were 3 levels of reasoning, each with two stages in progressing order. Level 1 is the preconventional stage, that consists of actions and behaviors being driven by obedience and eventually, self reward. This is seen as the least developed way of thinking. The second level, known as the conventional level had the notion that our behavior is driven by social approval and conforming to the social order. Lastly, level 3 is called the post conventional stage, and is the most developed way of reasoning. Here, peopleâ€™s actions are influenced by social order, individual rights and universal ethics. 

Overall, we can compare both these theories since they are somewhat related to each other. They both focus on cognitive thinking and what influences our behaviour and actions. Both illustrated the fundamental skills and critical thinking we obtained, and how we may have developed them. They both showed important milsteones to know when we have reached a certain stage. Specifically, both related their findings to children as they aged into adolescence. 

Both the Moral Development Theory and Cognitive Theory have garnered a lot of attention over the years, and have been important in understanding how the human mind functions. They were both detrimental to the evolution of our knowledge and paved the way for research and learning in childhood development.

nodes.title: Comparison of the Moral Development and Cognitive Theory

typeData.textContent:
During week 7, there was a focus on different theories of lifespan development. In particular, we learned about emotional, personality and cognitive changes throughout childhood to late adulthood. It was interesting to notice how some theories â€œpiggybackedâ€ on concepts of a preceding psychologist, For example, the Moral Development Theory, created by Lawrence Kohlberg, was built upon the foundation of another theory. One of the most famous psychologists, Jean piaget, pioneered the 4 stages of development at different times in our lives, known as the Cognitive Theory of development. Both of these social psychologists focused on the childhood aspect of development, and were weary to the idea of cognitive thoughts and how they affect our behaviour. 

In the Cognitive Theory of Development, Jean Piaget proposed that there were four concrete stages. These were known as the sensorimotor, preoperational, concrete operational and formal operational. The sensorimotor stage focused on children who learned about the world through senses and motor behavior, and was during the ages of 0-2 years old. Afterwards, the preoperational phase, lasting from 2-7, the children begin to use language, display egocentrism, and have still not developed an understanding of conservation. The third stage at 7-11 years old is known as the concrete operational stage, where they begin to harness a knowledge of conservation, and use reasoning and logic to solve dilemmas. The last stage, formal development, involves people 11+ years old. This stage focused on abstract thinking. 

This was a great theory to explain the evolution of our behaviour and thoughts as we age, and which milestones we surpass every few years that contribute to our development. Armed with this knowledge, Kohldberg took these principles to create the Moral Development Theory. This involves moral reasoning, and is directly correlated to our cognitive development. 

The Moral Development Theory focused on childhood to adolescence development and our moral reasoning as we aged. According to Kohlberg, there were 3 levels of reasoning, each with two stages in progressing order. Level 1 is the preconventional stage, that consists of actions and behaviors being driven by obedience and eventually, self reward. This is seen as the least developed way of thinking. The second level, known as the conventional level had the notion that our behavior is driven by social approval and conforming to the social order. Lastly, level 3 is called the post conventional stage, and is the most developed way of reasoning. Here, peopleâ€™s actions are influenced by social order, individual rights and universal ethics. 

Overall, we can compare both these theories since they are somewhat related to each other. They both focus on cognitive thinking and what influences our behaviour and actions. Both illustrated the fundamental skills and critical thinking we obtained, and how we may have developed them. They both showed important milsteones to know when we have reached a certain stage. Specifically, both related their findings to children as they aged into adolescence. 

Both the Moral Development Theory and Cognitive Theory have garnered a lot of attention over the years, and have been important in understanding how the human mind functions. They were both detrimental to the evolution of our knowledge and paved the way for research and learning in childhood development.

typeData.textContent:
Jean Piaget believed that there were four stages a child needed to go through in order for their cognitive abilities to function as best as possible. The four stages are sensorimotor, preoperational, concrete operational, and formal operational. The sensorimotor (0-2) stage involves gathering world experience through senses and actions, and has developmental issues with object permanence and stranger anxiety involved. The preoperational stage (ages 2-6), uses words and images to represent things, but lacks logical reasoning. This stage has developmental issues with pretend play, language development, and egocentrism. Concrete operational is the third stage (ages 7-11). This stage leads to understanding concrete events and analogies logically; ability to perform arithmetic operations. The developmental issues are conservation mathematical transformations. The last is formal operation which utilizes abstract reasoning. The developmental issues are moral reasoning. 

 Jean Piaget believed that children learn by developing schemata. Schemata are concepts (mental notes) that help them categorize objects, places, people, etc. This helps them recognize and differentiate between everything in the world around them. When children pick up new schemata and learn new information, they adjust their previous schemata through assimilation and accommodation. Assimilation is when they take in new information about the world and compare it to their previous knowledge. Accommodation is changing their previous knowledge based off of their new found information. This process happens best when children interact with their environment. However, it is not enough for the child to only be involved in the environment, the parents need to be as well. For example, let's say a child thinks that the moon is following his family in the car. He tells his parents that the moon follows them wherever they go. Because the parents are interacting with their child and the environment they are in, they can tell their child that the moon does not actually follow them. This will cause accommodation for the child's previous schemata. This needs to happen for children to learn. If a child's parents are not interacting with them, they cannot learn adequate information, and hence their IQ could be lower than its potential. As one's IQ is determined by nature and nurture, the environment one grows up in is as important as their genetics. 

Low SES families are proven to interact less with their children, resulting in their child's learning being hindered. By understanding Jean Piaget's theory of how children's cognitive development occurs, we can understand how it is necessary for parents to interact with their children at a young age for assimilation and accommodation to occur, which are both necessary for cognitive development.

nodes.description: This node highlights the eight stages of Psychosocial Theory of Development that are thoroughly explained in the linked video.

typeData.textContent:
1. Infancy: Resolve the task of Trust vs Mistrust (Identifying a responsive or unresponsive caregivers -> TWO OUTCOMES: safe predictable space or anxious and fearful)
2. Toddlers: Resolve the task of Autonomy vs Shame and Doubt (Establishing independence or dependance -> TWO OUTCOMES: independence or low self-esteem)
3. Preschool: Resolve the task of initiative vs guilt (Learning to plan and achieve goals while interacting with other -> TWO OUTCOMES: self confidence or guilty)
4. Elementary: Resolve the task of Industry vs inferiority (children beginning to compare themselves to others to see how they measure up -> TWO OUTCOMES: sense of pride or inferior feelings)
5. Adolescence: Resolve the task of Identity vs role confusion (Constant search for identity -> TWO OUTCOMES: strong sense of identity or weak sense of identity)
6. Early Adulthood: Resolve the task of Intimacy vs isolation (developing a positive self-concept in adolescence -> TWO OUTCOMES: strong intimate relations or lonely emotional isolation)
7. Middle Adulthood: Resolve the task of Generativity vs stagnation (finding your life's work and contributing to the development of others: volunteering, mentoring and raising children or not contributing to the development of others -> TWO OUTCOMES: good self development or stagnation/little self-improvement)
8. Late Adulthood: Resolve the task of Integrity vs despair (Evaluating past life experiences and coming to a conclusion -> TWO OUTCOMES: A sense of satisfaction or a sense of failure)

nodes.title: Marcia's Identity Statuses (Fernando Ng; group: fernathan)
nodes.description: This node will cover Marcia's 4 identity statuses and follow up on previous nodes content.

typeData.textContent:
Continuing on Nathanâ€™s node, I will be expanding on Marciaâ€™s findings and theories.

James Marcia, a theorist inspired by Eriksonâ€™s beliefs of identity formation, crisis and confusion, worked on a theory primarily focussing on the relationship between an individualâ€™s goals and commitment with respect to their identity. Marcia would then separate four main points of his theory into â€˜identity statusesâ€™ and this would be used to differentiate developmental identity points possible in an individualâ€™s life. 

1.	Identity Diffusion â€“ When an individual lacks commitment or exploration to an ideology/identity

2.	Identity Foreclosure â€“ When an individual presents a high level of commitment but often lacks exploration in other ideologies

3.	Identity Moratorium â€“ When an individual presents a high level of exploration but lacks commitment to any identity/ideology

4.	Identity Achievement â€“ When an individual presents both a high level of commitment and exploration and decides on an identity/ideology to stand by

Following up on Nathanâ€™s example of toxic masculinity and emotional repression, we can create an example on how it may relate to one of the previously mentioned stages being identity diffusion. For our imaginary individual Bob, he is considered to be in the first identity status and stays at home without knowing a purpose in what to do with his life. His strict father Joe, who is home all the time thanks to COVID, is infuriated anytime he sees Bob slacking off and goes off on a vocal rampage whenever Bob speaks. Because of this, Bob is uncomfortable and tries to show little to no emotion in hopes or his father to speak nicer to him and hide his pain from the verbal abuse.

If an individual (such as Bob) is under the identity diffusion stage, it is likely that the individual is avoidant to discomfort and seeks pleasure and comfort. 

Now creating an example on the same topic as before, this time in the identity moratorium stage described by Nathanâ€™s node. Imagine Bob going around the city and applying for any job available on the block and coming home with news of his progress. His father with his vocal fury replies with a statement challenging his goals and future for the 457th time. At this point Bob fully represses his feelings and emotions towards his father and begins to have feelings of confusion and self-doubt, delaying any commitment as he thinks about his choices.

This is just an example and fictional, with the focus on parental influence and Bobâ€™s seeking adventure for his fatherâ€™s approval of Bobâ€™s identity.
